What are supernovae?

Some 170,000 light-years away, in the Large Magellanic Cloud, lies the supernova remnant N132D (NASA 2005). Thousands of years ago, a massive star met a violent end in a cataclysmic explosion. Today, its remnants continue to glow brightly, spanning 80 light-years and containing material equivalent to 600 Suns (NASA 2005). But how did this remnant form? What forces shaped its intricate structure?
